message_1: What is the period and amplitude of the following function: y = 3sin(2x - π/3)?
message_2:
To find the period and amplitude of the function y = 3sin(2x - π/3), we need to analyze the coefficients and the argument of the sine function.

Amplitude:
The amplitude is the absolute value of the coefficient in front of the sine function. In this case, the amplitude is |3| = 3.

Period:
The period of a sine function is given by the formula (2π) / |B|, where B is the coefficient of x inside the sine function. In this case, B = 2. So, the period is (2π) / |2| = (2π) / 2 = π.

So, the amplitude of the function is 3, and the period is π.
